results.content: I was so eager to start this course b/c there aren't many node rest api courses w/ mongo.  I was happy with the example and basic JS tutorial.  However, setting up the skeleton section is where is went south for me.  Jack isn't teaching, he's coding while you watch and not explaining what he's writing or why he's doing it that way.  There is so much that wasn't covered the in the JS basics.  Then, way too many dependancies.  If any of those packages fail b/c of system or package conflicts, then the whole rest of the course is ruined and useless (which happened to me).  Lastly, it was so painful to watch Jack setup the package file for those dependancies.  Next time, provide the file and move on.  Needless to say, I was not able to complete the course.

results.content:
I am about 60% of the way through this course and I just wanted to write and say how great the instructor and material it is.  There are a lot of options out there for online training, and frankly, most of them fall short in every area.

This course is a great example of being taken through all of the steps from beginning to end, without leaving anything out.  

Jack does a tremendous job of presenting some pretty complex topics, and at the end, you have a product that you can use on y our own, and apply to anything you want to do!  

These set of videos are not just a one off tutorial that you will find on some other site either that can only apply to a specific topic in a vacuum .  You really can take the knowledge learned here and apply it your own projects the same day you learn it.  

If you are at all on the fence about this course, sign up and you will be glad you did.  

Jack and all of the guys over at devslopes have a real passion for teaching and learning and are passionate about technology and all it has to offer!  Do yourself a huge favor and take this class!

results.content:
- The instructor is listed as Mark Price. It isn't Mark Price.
- In order to complete the course, you're expected to sign up for a paid-service (droplet), along with other things like certification for https, etc. This should be mentioned up front before purchasing this course.

- The instructor was error-prone and caused prologned agony by deciding to refactor mid-way through
- This wasn't helped by him using Atom instead of a full-fat IDE
- His approach to working through the code was simply to write it. No explanation of what he was doing or why.
- No explanation of why we're transpiling from ES6 to ES2015 with babel.
- No explanation of mongoose
- No explanation of passport
- No explanation of express
- The delivery was dull and uninformative. You could have just given me the completed project to download and saved me 18 hours of agony.

Node.js - This is pretty well explained and to the point. After a couple of sessions one can understand the what is really happening and then can develop his own node.js rest API's. 

Android - Since i am beginner to android, found it tough to follow the course content and debugging the code. Though the content is well organized , few concepts could have been explained in depth rather than directly starting with coding. For example , why there is a need to add activity and how activity is connected to other components in android project structure. 

iOS - not followed it :-) :-) 

As said before i feel these things are hard to follow as a beginner , but if you are familiar with android development then this is a course to start with building your own API for android.

results.content:
I want to start by saying there's nothing wrong with the instructor or the course as is. I realize the name should have tipped me off to the fact that this really was for beginners. I just didn't think this would be literally for a beginner.

Overall, I found it very slow and drawn out. I'd say if you're new to coding and have never written anything more than a "hello world" program, this is a great place to start.

The instructor covers a lot of topics in a very broad and easy to understand way. However, if you're a seasoned developer looking to pick up Node.js and related technology, this is going to be painful. I had the video on 2x and I still found myself skipping past lots of sections.

Also, much of the material has little to do with Node.js API development with real world examples.  Much of it is simple CRUD operations, and I found myself having to check other resources to get a better understanding of building a useful Node project.

Being a broad overview, the corse will also show you how to build clients that allow you to consume the API you're building. Again, useful for a general overview of APIs, but I personally think that should have been a bonus video, or a separate course.

tldr;

Watching on 2x is still too slow.

Course is very general and good for total rookies/newbs.

Seasoned Coders looking to catch up on the new hotness (Node.JS & Express) should look elsewhere.

results.content: I fully admit I drink the Devslopes KoolAid. There are a ton of other courses out there that have pointed me in the right direction as far as programming, but as a far providing a fully integrated suite of tutorials and help, Devslopes is peerless. I was so lucky to stumble across their early courses and get into the full program. The great thing about their courses is that I can learn about the exact concept I want, and then stop and skip to another course on another concept without missing a beat. Imagine looking at a college's course catalog, and being able to take whichever 100 or 400 level course you need at the time. Now imagine being able to select individual lectures in each of those courses, without having go through the trouble of spending an entire semester just waiting to get to the lectures you actually care about (I still highly recommend going through each course start to finish though, they're great). The point I'm trying to make is that Devslopes is the best of every world. Takes Mark's courses.

results.content:
The course was good, I just wasn't a fan of the structure of the project. After going through the entire API portion of the course, I found myself going back and refactoring the entire project in a more sensible project structure to my liking. I didn't like how { config, db } was getting carried around the entire app for no reason at all. Also the author was placing imports in files that didn't need them to be imported. 

eg; foodtruck controller imported mongoose...Why? When you import your model, your model already has the reference to the mongo instance to do ALL mongoose db operations without having to import mongoose into the controller file. The project was littered with stuff like this.

I did enjoy the ios/android/production deploy portions of the course though. Overall good course, just a lot of redundancy.

results.content:
This is an early review - I'm on a few sections in on this REST API course, but I'm familiar enough now with Mark Price and the Devslopes team to know that this is another quality course from them.

Previously I've taken Swift, React, Angular, Sketch, Android and other courses through Devslopes (highly recommend all of those courses btw!!), so when I wanted to dive deeper into REST APIs I figured this would be the place to start.  Jack from the Devslopes team is heading this one up - and just from the first several videos I've already picked up lots of new info.  

That's the kind of courses you get from Mark, Jack, Pearson and the rest of the Devslopes folks - informative, to the point, and all with a great community of support.

Definitely recommend checking this out if you're wanting to learn more about REST APIs.

results.content:
Good course, just a bit overwhelming. The instructor tends to write the code in a not-so-good way. One example, is he imports modules/files before they are even created. That looks all good when you have the whole API written down and you're just re-writing it for the camera, but when you're following it lecture by lecture from a student's perspective, it is weird to import something before actually creating that module first and knowing exactly what it does/will do.

Another thing, is calling functions with parameters that are not ever used. All I'm saying, is that the flow of the course can be improved.

Overall, it's still a decent course and worth checking out.

results.content:
More of a high-level code-along rather than a learning course.

Pros: 
- Great production value
- Great instructor
- Easy to follow along with

Cons
- Doesn't get much into the theory of "Why am I writing this line of code" at all. Just felt like I was typing in code to keep up.

All in all not upset about purchasing this course ($15 on sale). Had I paid full price I would not be very impressed.

I did not need to go over the native app portion so perhaps it would be more helpful to those who do.

I left the course with a basic understanding of how MongoDb works, but would not be in a position to code a Node/Mongo app on my own afterwards without a lot of referring back to this course.

results.content:
The videos are generally well laid out. I appreciate the approach of building a project from the start. Couple of suggestions: 

- It would be helpful for the presenter to indicate where parts of the API reinforce concepts previously learned in the JS basics portion of the videos. Several times he makes references to the term "destructuring" and I don't recall him teaching this during the JS portion of the video.
- Some of the code that is available to download is not the same as what is taught. In at least one example there is still a holdover of ES5 syntax in the ZIP file resources when he illustrates ES6 "fat arrow" functions in the videos.
- The quizzes are too easy. They are not very deep.

That said, the material itself is presented in a generally clear way. The presenter is really engaging, and the depth of topic sufficient enough to get people started quickly. Keeping in mind that API design and development is a topic that entire books are dedicated to, this course is a great intro.

results.content:
Jack's a great guy who's enjoyable to listen to and hang out with while we build out an API.

After reviewing some javascript in the initial lessons, however, expect to simply get dragged through the content without much explanation to the "how and why" that is so essential to understanding what you're doing.

As soon as we finished the API and prepared for deployment, this course transformed entirely to this paint-by-numbers approach that killed it for me. Custom backend configurations with Digital Ocean, Ubuntu, domain-registration, and SSL certificates seem entirely out of the scope of a course designed for beginners. I kept asking myself, "Why are we not using Heroku? What the hell is going on?" Needless to say, like most courses not posted literally yesterday, the layouts and menu options of the various new services used had since updated. Following along with the lesson became a lesson in itself. All I wanted to do was build an API and put it on my portfolio!

Bottom line--I was able to happily and successfully complete all of the modules up until Deployment. I have a simple, functional API that works as advertised and served as useful practice. For the ~$10 I paid, I consider the money well spent, but due to the considerations above, couldn't rate it higher than "satisfactory".

Cheers and happy coding.

results.content:
I'm quite disappointed by this course. First, I wouldn't recommend it to a beginner. The instructor goes too fast on a number of simple subjects and one should already know a language before taking this course (it's my case hopefully). This course is designed for Android or Swift developers who already use those skills in their jobs and want to do server side APIs. Saying that it is for total beginners is misleading.

Second it doesn't go far enough either. The API that you build is one of a very simple kind. It's good to begin with and to learn the basics. But a good 165€ course should also provide at least another exercise with a more complex API to really get the idea.

It's a shame because you just needed to extend your FoodTruck API a bit and give more initial knowledge. But without this work done I'm quite lost and I know that I have only scratched the surface even though I could have take another course.

results.content:
My main complaint is about the content. I bought this course to learn node.js So I don't know why 35% of the course is learning iOS and Android. I would rather learn more advanced node stuff. And leave at most 10% for the mobile platform integration, if not out completely.

I mean I bought this course because Udemy marked it as a "top seller" but if I wanted to learn iOS or Android, I would buy any of the other Devslopes courses.

The other thing is, suddenly I felt like I just copied and pasted code because there was no real explanation of what was going on under the hood of what we were doing. For example, the middleware file we created wasn't even used at all.

results.content: Absolutely horrendous. Take this course if you want to just copy and paste code and have absolutely no idea why it works or know anything about its functionality. Constantly had to look at documentation myself to understand anything. Might as well consult the documentation as they actually explain why something works. Jack does a great job in writing several lines of code, gives no explanation and continues to write more code repeating the process. Constantly, cutting the video to review his own notes making it seem like he doesn't know the content himself and is just copy and pasting himself. It's understandable to review one's notes but after watching several videos it gives off the impression he doesn't know how to explain it to his audience. No enthusiasm, no explanation as to why he choose the architectural approach to his code. Definitely not for anyone with no prior Swift or Node experience, you will be completely lost.

results.content:
Good but it might be puzzling if you don't have a good Javascript base.

There are a lot of professional tips not found in other courses, specially for the server configuration. It maintains a typical approach to API representation by using controllers, with an appropriate separation of concerns (ie. file structure).

The tutor explains almost every package is donwloaded, with some exceptions. Babel and lint are not explained so you better know some about them in advance.

results.content: I've tried a number of Udemy courses, and this has been one of my best experiences. The instructor is clear and explains things very well. There is a lot of breadth to the course material, and if you are familiar with JavaScript and ES6, you can skip a large portion. That said, there is still plenty of content outside of these videos.  At times I wish the author would explain a bit more about use cases of particular elements explained in the JS/ES6 tutorials, for example when to use IIFE vs named functions, etc.  But I honestly believe that what he is leaving out is largely not in the scope of the course. Very happy overall.

results.content:
The instructor does a decent job explaining concepts. I would suggest going a little more in-depth -- though -- for people who are new to JavaScript or even programming in general for that matter (good thing I'm not new to it). He does provide links for basic JavaScript learning and tutorials, but briefly re-iterating certain concepts while we're coding along could be useful. 

This course seems put together like it had a deadline. Other than that, it helps build a good foundation for people like me who want to get started on making their own API's with industry-recognized best practices.
